title: Weather: Sydney swelters through ANOTHER scorcher
text: comments Sydney was expected to be spared a third consecutive day of searing temperatures on Sunday. But residents will have to suffer through one more day of 40C heat before a cool change finally brings relief from the fierce heatwave which has plagued the east coast. By 10.30am, the mercury had risen to a blistering 31C in the city, smashing the expected maximum of 27C. Sydneysiders will have to suffer through one more day of 40C heat before a cool change finally brings relief By 10.30am, the mercury had risen to a blistering 31C in the city, smashing the expected maximum of 27C. Plenty of people turned up to Bronte Beach for a morning swim A Bureau of Meteorology spokesperson said the city's morning heat would gradually ease The mercury rose above 40C in 55 regional towns on Saturday, with Ivanhoe Airport recording a blistering 47.6 just before 4pm In the west, temperatures will reach 40C in Richmond and 39C in Penrith by mid afternoon. A Bureau of Meteorology spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia the city's morning heat would gradually ease. 'We've got a pretty good southerly blowing now, especially in coastal suburbs. The city has reached 31C but it will probably just drop away through the high 20s,' he said. Sydneysiders could see temperatures fall to as low as 18C in parts of the city overnight, before a balmy maximum of 27C on Monday. On Saturday night, the mercury fell to 24.5C in the city and 23C in the outer suburbs after one of the hottest days on record A view of Bondi Beach on Sunday morning when temperatures had already reached 31C Sasha Boljevic (R) from Parramatta takes a selfie while sunbaking with her friend Maria Lukasheva from Silvania (L) on the grassy knowl at North Bondi A woman enjoys the hot weather as she sunbathes on the sands of Bondi Beach On Saturday night, the mercury fell to 24.5C in the city and 23C in the outer suburbs after one of the hottest days on record. Temperatures rose above 40C in 55 regional towns, with Ivanhoe Airport recording a blistering 47.6 just before 4pm. The city reached 36.2C as the west sweltered through Saturday, with Richmond recording 47C and Penrith 46.9C. While temperatures aren't tipped to get any higher than 31C in the city on Sunday, much of NSW will remain above 40C, as fire dangers reach unprecedented levels. NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Paul Best said rapid response units had been deployed in the state's Central Ranges, North Western and Greater Hunter regions. Sydney's CBD reached 36.2C as the city's west sweltered through Saturday, with Richmond recording 47C and Penrith 46.9C Two woman are seen escaping the heat at Bondi Beach on Sunday morning In the west, temperatures will reach 40C in Richmond and 39C in Penrith by mid afternoon on Sudnay Hundreds flocked to Cronulla Beach in Sydney's south to deal with the scorching temperatures 'For the Greater Hunter, the catastrophic conditions are predicted to start around midday, but it will be escalating rapidly from 10am,' Mr Best said on Sunday morning. 'The whole area falls under the catastrophic fire danger, so we've got very dangerous fire conditions right across the Hunter.' Queensland's heatwave continues to sweep across the state, sending temperature records tumbling in the process. 'Much of southern Queensland will see temperatures in the low to mid 40s with Brisbane forecast to hit 39C and Ipswich potentially reaching 43C,' Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Sam Campbell said. Above, Burleigh Heads Beach on the Gold Coast Much of southern Queensland will see temperatures in the low to mid 40s with Brisbane forecast to hit 39C In Queensland, a number of heat records tumbled on Saturday Birdsville is set to be the hottest place in the state by mid afternoon and could break temperature records with a top of 47C forecast. A number of heat records tumbled on Saturday, with Warwick, Applethorpe and Oakey all having their hottest ever days. Temperatures in the southwest should dip back below 40C following the arrival of a trough on Monday. In Victoria, the brutal heatwave is finally over. In the state's north, residents have endured their last day of above 40C weather as they welcome the cool change. The temperature in Mildura hit a sweltering 44.4C on Saturday, it's fourth day straight of above 40C weather. The regional city will only reach 25C on Sunday while Melbourne won't even hit 20C.
